tn.text: Moses continues to speak to the Israelites as if they are one person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
The word "Israel" is a metonym for the people of Israel. AT: "Listen, people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"to take the land from"

This is an exaggeration that emphasizes how frightened the people were because the cities were so large and strong. See how you translated similar words in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:01:26|1:28]]. AT: "have very tall walls" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

Descendants of the Anak people who were very large and fierce. See how you translated similar words in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:01:26|1:28]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Who can stand before the sons of Anak?
tn.text: This means that the sons of Anak were powerful and people were afraid of them. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "There is no one who can defend himself against the sons of Anak." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Moses continues to speak to the Israelites as if they are one person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
"now"
Yahweh is powerful and able to destroy the armies of the other nations. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"make them weak so you can control them"
Moses continues to speak to the Israelites as if they are one person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: Do not say in your heart
tn.text: Here "in your heart" means "in your thoughts." AT: "Do not think to yourselves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"has driven the other peoples out"
Moses continues to speak to the Israelites as if they are one person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
This is an idiom. "because you always thought and desired the right things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: so that he may make come true the word
tn.text: Here the metonym "the word" refers to what God has promised. AT: "so that he may fulfill the promise" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: your ancestors, to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob
tn.text: Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob are the "ancestors" of whom Moses is speaking.
Moses continues to speak to the Israelites as if they are one person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Moses continues to speak to the Israelites as if they are one person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Moses repeats the same command both positively and negatively to emphasize the importance of remembering. AT: "Be careful to remember" (See: [[:en:ta;vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Here "you" refers to the Israelites that are present with Moses and also the Israelites of the previous generation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: you came to this place, you have been rebellious ... you provoked ... with you to destroy you
tn.text: All instances of "you" are plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
This refers to the Jordan River Valley.
Moses is reminding the people of Israel what happened in the past.

tn.ref: the tablets of stone, the tablets of the covenant that Yahweh made with you
tn.text: Here the second phrase clarifies that "the tablets of stone" are the ones on which God wrote the Ten Commandments. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"40 days and 40 nights" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: on them was written everything just like all the words that Yahweh announced to you
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh wrote on them the same words he had said to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Yahweh announced ... out of the middle of the fire
tn.text: It was as if Yahweh were a person standing in the middle of a fire and speaking with a loud voice.

tn.ref: on the day of the assembly
tn.text: The abstract noun "assembly" can be expressed as the verb "gather together." AT: "on the day when you Israelites all came and met together in one place" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"40 days and 40 nights" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: the two tablets of stone, the tablets of the covenant
tn.text: The second phrase clarifies that "the two tablets of stone" are the ones on which God wrote the Ten Commandments. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"your people ... are doing what is wrong." Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:04:15|4:16]].

tn.ref: They have quickly turned aside out of the path that I commanded them
tn.text: Moses speaks as if obeying God's commands were walking along a path. AT: "They have already disobeyed my commands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: blot out their name from under heaven
tn.text: "make their name disappear completely" or "kill them all so no one will ever remember them." See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:07:23|7:24]].
Moses continues reminding the people of Israel what happened in the past.
The word "behold" here shows that Moses was surprised by what he saw.

The Israelites of the earlier generation had asked Aaron to make a metal calf so they could worship it. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: You had quickly turned aside out of the path that Yahweh had commanded you
tn.text: Moses speaks as if obeying God's commands were walking along a path. AT: "You had quickly disobeyed what Yahweh had commanded you." Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:09:11|9:12]].
Moses continues reminding the people of Israel about what happened in the past.

tn.ref: I broke them before your eyes
tn.text: Here "your eyes" is a synecdoche for the people of Israel. AT: "I broke them right in front of you" or "I broke them where you could see them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"lay with my face on the ground." This is a way of showing that Yahweh was great and Moses was not.
"40 days and 40 nights" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
Moses continues reminding the people of Israel what happened in the past.

tn.ref: I was afraid of the anger and hot displeasure with which Yahweh was angry enough against you to destroy you
tn.text: The words "anger and hot displeasure" are a metonym for what Yahweh would do because he was angry and displeased. AT: "Yahweh was angry at you—he was extremely displeased with you—he was angry enough to destroy you, and so I was afraid of what he would do"
Moses continues reminding the people of Israel about what happened in the past.

tn.ref: I took ... burned ... beat ... ground ... threw
tn.text: Moses probably commanded other men to do the actual work. AT: "I had people take ... burn ... beat ... grind ... throw"
the golden calf. AT: "the idol you sinned by making" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Moses continues to remind the people of Israel about what happened in the past.
These are names of places that the people of Israel went through while they were in the wilderness. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
They were on low land, and the land Yahweh had told them to take was in the hills, so they had to go uphill to get to it.
The word "commandment" is a metonym for Yahweh himself. AT: "rebelled against Yahweh; you did not obey the commandment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "his voice" means what God had said. AT: "obey what he said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: from the day that I knew you
tn.text: "from the time I began to lead you." Some translations read "from the day that he knew you," the day that Yahweh first knew them.
Moses continues reminding the people of Israel about what happened in the past.
"lay with my face on the ground." Translate this as it is in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:09:17|9:18]].
"40 days and 40 nights" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
Moses speaks as if Yahweh had rescued the Israelites by paying money to free them from slavery. AT: "you have rescued" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "greatness" is a metonym for Yahweh's great power. AT: "through your great power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "a mighty hand" refers to Yahweh's power. AT: "with your mighty power." Similar words also appear in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:04:34|4:34]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Moses continues praying to Yahweh so that he may not destroy the people of Israel.
This is an idiom. AT: "Remember" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: so that the land from where you brought us
tn.text: The words "the land" are a metonym for the people of Egypt. AT: "so that the people of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"can say"

tn.ref: by your great strength and by the display of your power
tn.text: These phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize the greatness of Yahweh's power that he used to rescue his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
